recentPerformance.hitRate: Texas 7-4 ATS this season, ranked #10 in CFP rankings
recentPerformance.recentForm: Georgia 6-4 ATS, but 8-1 ATS at home in Sanford Stadium
recentPerformance.homeRecord: Road game for Texas at notoriously hostile Sanford Stadium
recentPerformance.cushion: Small +4.5 spread suggested oddsmakers expected competitive game

keyFactors.title: College Football Playoff Implications
keyFactors.description: Texas ranked #10 with CFP hopes on line. Expected to show up motivated in hostile environment. Small spread (+4.5) indicated oddsmakers projected competitive game in 27-24 range.

keyFactors.title: Texas Offensive Firepower
keyFactors.description: Texas averaging 32.1 PPG (18th nationally), led by efficient passing attack. Expected to move ball against Georgia defense allowing 18.3 PPG. Projected to score 24+ points.

keyFactors.title: Competitive SEC Matchup
keyFactors.description: Both teams battling for SEC positioning. Texas had shown resilience in tough road environments this season. Line of +4.5 suggested belief in Texas's ability to keep it within one possession.

keyFactors.title: Underdog Value with Playoff Team
keyFactors.description: Getting 4.5 points with top-10 team in CFP hunt represented value. Texas had talent to compete with Georgia - just needed to keep it close.

riskFactors: Sanford Stadium one of toughest road environments in college football
Georgia's defense elite, allowing just 18.3 PPG
Gunner Stockton emerging as efficient QB (completion % in high 70s)
Texas playing cross-division opponent with limited film
Georgia 8-1 ATS at home this season - dominant in Athens

gunnerStockton.note: Completely dominated - elite accuracy and decision-making

nateFrazier.note: Controlled clock in 4th quarter, kept Texas offense off field

texasQB.note: Completely overwhelmed by Georgia defense, couldn't sustain drives

quarterBreakdown.description: Competitive start with Georgia taking 7-3 lead. Texas defense held initially, offense managed field goal. Game still within script at end of Q1.
Georgia extended lead to 21-10 at halftime. Stockton threw 2 TD passes. Texas managed 1 TD but couldn't keep pace. Warning signs emerging - Georgia controlling possession (19:12 to 10:48 in H1).
Georgia extended lead to 28-10. Stockton threw another TD pass. Texas offense completely stifled - couldn't convert third downs (0-4 in Q3). Georgia's defense suffocating.

Complete blowout. Georgia outscored Texas 21-0 in 4th quarter alone, turning competitive game into rout. Stockton threw 4th TD pass, Frazier controlled clock with rushing. Texas had no answers - final score 35-10.

gameResults.whenMissed: Texas failed to cover when Georgia scored 3rd touchdown in 4th quarter with 6:24 remaining, extending lead to 35-10 (25 points). At that moment, +4.5 was mathematically eliminated. Georgia's 21-0 4th quarter destroyed any cover hope.
gameResults.turningPoint: Georgia's dominant 4th quarter (21-0 run) transformed competitive game into blowout. When game was 14-10 at half, spread still alive. Georgia's halftime adjustments and Stockton's efficiency (24-of-29) completely overwhelmed Texas. The 4th quarter avalanche exposed fundamental talent gap.
gameResults.gamePace: Georgia controlled tempo throughout - 35:09 TOP vs 24:51 for Texas. Texas couldn't sustain drives (4-13 on third downs) while Georgia converted at 57% clip (8-14). Georgia's ball control suffocated Texas's offense and wore down defense.
gameResults.teamOffense: Texas managed only 274 total yards (89 rush, 185 pass) against Georgia's elite defense. Couldn't establish run game (89 yards) or pass effectively (18-31, 0 TDs). Georgia's 357 yards (267 pass, 90 rush) showcased balanced attack that Texas couldn't stop.

whatWentWrong.title: Gunner Stockton's Breakout Performance
whatWentWrong.description: Georgia QB Stockton went 24-of-29 (82.8%) for 267 yards and 4 TDs. This elite efficiency completely shredded Texas defense. Didn't anticipate Stockton playing at this level - career-best performance destroyed Texas secondary.

whatWentWrong.title: Georgia's Home Dominance Underestimated
whatWentWrong.description: Georgia entered 8-1 ATS at Sanford Stadium this season. Should have weighted home-field advantage more heavily. Sanford Stadium's hostile environment plus Georgia's talent created insurmountable challenge for Texas.

whatWentWrong.title: 4th Quarter Collapse (21-0)
whatWentWrong.description: Game was 14-10 at half - spread still very much alive. Georgia's 21-0 4th quarter avalanche turned competitive game into blowout. Texas had no answers, couldn't respond to adversity.

whatWentWrong.title: Texas Offense Completely Overwhelmed
whatWentWrong.description: Texas managed only 274 total yards and 10 points against Georgia defense. Couldn't establish run (89 yards) or pass (0 TDs). Complete offensive failure - averaged 32.1 PPG but scored only 10.

whatWentWrong.title: Time of Possession Destroyed
whatWentWrong.description: Georgia dominated TOP 35:09 to 24:51. Texas couldn't sustain drives (4-13 third downs), meaning defense was on field constantly. Fatigue factor led to 4th quarter collapse.

statisticalContext.vsSeasonAverage: Texas's 10 points was 22.1 below season average (32.1 PPG). Georgia's 35 points was 16.7 above their defensive average (18.3 PPG allowed). Complete statistical reversal.
statisticalContext.vsRecentForm: Stockton's 82.8% completion rate and 4 TDs represented career-high performance. Texas's 274 total yards was season-low. Every metric pointed to dominant Georgia victory.
statisticalContext.vsPropLine: Missed +4.5 by 20.5 points. Final margin of 25 points (35-10) was catastrophic beat. Line movement (from +5 to +4.5) didn't matter - wrong side entirely.
statisticalContext.percentileRanking: Georgia's 82.8% completion rate ranked in 97th percentile for NCAAF games this season. Stockton's 4 TD performance was elite. Texas had no defensive answer.

postGameAnalysis.wasNormalVariance: No. This was not variance - this was fundamental misread of team quality and matchup dynamics. Georgia's home dominance (8-1 ATS at Sanford Stadium) should have been weighted heavier. Stockton's elite performance (24-of-29, 4 TDs) wasn't luck - it was talent executing perfectly. Texas being held to 10 points (22.1 below average) showed Georgia's defense was simply superior. The 21-0 4th quarter wasn't variance - it was talent gap exposing itself. This was bad process meeting reality.

closingLineValue.verdict: Slight positive CLV but completely irrelevant. We bet at +4.5 (-104) and closing was +4 (-110), meaning we got half-point better number. However, losing by 25 points makes CLV discussion moot. This wasn't a case of good bet with bad variance - this was wrong side entirely. CLV doesn't validate fundamentally flawed handicap.

keyTakeaways: Georgia's home dominance (8-1 ATS at Sanford Stadium) should have been weighted heavier - critical data point ignored
Gunner Stockton's elite performance (24-of-29, 82.8%, 4 TDs) exposed fundamental talent gap
Texas held to 10 points (22.1 below season average) showed Georgia defense was overwhelming
4th quarter collapse (21-0 Georgia run) turned competitive game into blowout - no Texas answers
Time of possession dominated by Georgia (35:09 vs 24:51) indicated complete game control
Small spread (+4.5) created false confidence - talent gap was much larger than oddsmakers suggested
Road underdog against elite home team in CFP-caliber environment is high-risk bet
Should have faded Texas on road against elite SEC defense - betting against Georgia at Sanford Stadium requires exceptional justification
For quantitative operations: home-field advantage in elite venues (Sanford Stadium) is 5-7 points, not 2-3
Lesson: When top-10 team is underdog by only 4.5 points against elite opponent at home, market might be undervaluing home team
verdict: Fundamental misread of matchup dynamics and home-field advantage. Georgia's 8-1 ATS record at Sanford Stadium should have been red flag - elite teams dominate at home in college football. Stockton's breakout (24-of-29, 4 TDs) and Texas's offensive collapse (10 points, 22.1 below average) exposed talent gap. The 21-0 4th quarter avalanche wasn't variance - it was superior team pulling away. Small spread (+4.5) created false confidence that this would be competitive. In reality, Georgia was significantly better team playing in elite home environment. Would not make this bet under any circumstances - wrong side entirely. Betting against Georgia at Sanford Stadium requires exceptional justification, which Texas +4.5 did not provide.
